subSections.title: Alternative forms
subSections.text: * In Japanese {{w|shinjitai}}, the bottom component is simplified to {{m|mul|大}}, rather than the traditional {{m|mul|犬||dog|sc=Hani}}. ** This character has technically been encoded in Unicode as {{m|mul|𦤀}} (U+26900) but is not used in Japanese computing; instead, the character {{m|mul|臭}} (U+81ED) changes appearance depending on the font. ** A {{w|CJK Compatibility Ideographs|CJK compatibility ideograph}} exists at U+FA5C for the {{w|kyūjitai}} form used in Japanese which contains {{l|mul|犬}} as its bottom component.

subSections.title: Glyph origin
subSections.text:
{{Han etym}}
{{Han compound|犬|t1=dog|自|t2=nose|ls=ic}}, referring to the dog's strong sense of smell.
